content.raw:
Hi @atmyers , this is pretty awesome.  I'm now going through it, and I was wondering if you had any ideas about:

 * Can we wrap the `ParticleProfile` stuff into the `create_profiles` or existing profile plot objects, to make it a single interface for both?
 * What else needs to happen to land this?
content.html:
Hi Andrew Myers , this is pretty awesome. I'm now going through it, and I was wondering if you had any ideas about:

  • Can we wrap the ParticleProfile stuff into the create_profiles or existing profile plot objects, to make it a single interface for both?
  • What else needs to happen to land this?

content.html: Can probably just use storage.values[:,:,fi] > 0.0 as the index, without the where

What about using a function pointer, since the arguments are identical?

if self.deposition == "cic":
    func = CICDeposit_2
elif self.deposition == "ngp":
    func = NGPDeposit_2
func( ...

content.raw: This will probably only work with patch datasets, but that's okay for now, as long as we don't rely on it elsewhere in functions we would want to apply to particle or octree.
content.html: This will probably only work with patch datasets, but that's okay for now, as long as we don't rely on it elsewhere in functions we would want to apply to particle or octree.

content.raw: ...and I think I know how we could get it to work everywhere, but it'll require using `process_particles`, which can be annoying.
content.html: ...and I think I know how we could get it to work everywhere, but it'll require using process_particles, which can be annoying.

content.raw: So this is a change of behavior, right?  Not necessarily a bad one, but a change.
content.html: So this is a change of behavior, right? Not necessarily a bad one, but a change.

content.raw: I think we don't need indices here, and can just use `mask`
content.html: I think we don't need indices here, and can just use mask

content.raw: I think that there may be issues with x, y, z ordering.  Since these never change, could they be set to be a template and the axis name supplied to them?  Then you'd string format with `ds.coordinates.axis_name[xax]` for instance.
content.html: I think that there may be issues with x, y, z ordering. Since these never change, could they be set to be a template and the axis name supplied to them? Then you'd string format with ds.coordinates.axis_name[xax] for instance.

content.raw:
Yes, it is. Before this change, when using with this function with particles that do not necessarily live on the mesh you've defined, it would deposit all of the ones outside the domain on the boundary cells. Now, it skips those particles instead. Come to think of it, I guess that doesn't do the right thing either, since some of those particles could contribute at least some of their mass with CIC deposition. But bracketing that, I need to handle this case for deposited phase plots, since it won't necessarily be the case that all the particles that live in the data_source belong on the mesh you've defined. 

The CICDeposit_3 function isn't necessary for the Particle Plot stuff, so I should probably leave it alone, though, and only do this in the 2D versions of the functions. I don't think CICDeposit_3 is currently used anywhere in yt, BTW - it looks like the CIC deposition stuff that gets called is in geomtery/particle_deposit.pyx instead.
content.html:
Yes, it is. Before this change, when using with this function with particles that do not necessarily live on the mesh you've defined, it would deposit all of the ones outside the domain on the boundary cells. Now, it skips those particles instead. Come to think of it, I guess that doesn't do the right thing either, since some of those particles could contribute at least some of their mass with CIC deposition. But bracketing that, I need to handle this case for deposited phase plots, since it won't necessarily be the case that all the particles that live in the data_source belong on the mesh you've defined.

The CICDeposit_3 function isn't necessary for the Particle Plot stuff, so I should probably leave it alone, though, and only do this in the 2D versions of the functions. I don't think CICDeposit_3 is currently used anywhere in yt, BTW - it looks like the CIC deposition stuff that gets called is in geomtery/particle_deposit.pyx instead.

content.raw: I think that everything got moved over to use the `particle_deposit` routines once we had them working -- but they won't work for your specific use case *yet*, so I think using this routine is fine.
content.html: I think that everything got moved over to use the particle_deposit routines once we had them working -- but they won't work for your specific use case yet, so I think using this routine is fine.

content.raw: This doesn't necessarily need to go in this PR - I added this in an attempt to address issues [917](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/issue/917) and [918](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/issue/918), along the lines of my comment in 918. I think this approach will technically work - you get the level for each particle, and does the right coarsening / interpolating at grid boundaries. But, it was veeeery slow, I think because it's grabbing all those ghost zones for particle fields. I think I should remove this from the Particle Plot PR.
content.html: This doesn't necessarily need to go in this PR - I added this in an attempt to address issues 917 and 918, along the lines of my comment in 918. I think this approach will technically work - you get the level for each particle, and does the right coarsening / interpolating at grid boundaries. But, it was veeeery slow, I think because it's grabbing all those ghost zones for particle fields. I think I should remove this from the Particle Plot PR.

content.raw: Thank you for taking a look at this - I have a good block of time today and I think we can take this to the hoop. I agree re: the create_profiles function. In addition to that, the main thing I want to include that isn't currently in there is to cleanly handle the case where just want to plot particles in a given color, instead of mapping some field to a colorbar.
content.html: Thank you for taking a look at this - I have a good block of time today and I think we can take this to the hoop. I agree re: the create_profiles function. In addition to that, the main thing I want to include that isn't currently in there is to cleanly handle the case where just want to plot particles in a given color, instead of mapping some field to a colorbar.

content.raw:
It doesn't normally make a difference, but I think you should be doing something like:

    field_info = data_source.ds._get_field_info(*bin_field)
    bf_units = field_info.units

The `_get_field_info` function does a little bit of extra inference and validation so that this will always work, particularly for user-defined fields that aren't necessarily a tuple in the `field_info` dictionary.
content.html:
It doesn't normally make a difference, but I think you should be doing something like:

field_info = data_source.ds._get_field_info(*bin_field)
bf_units = field_info.units

The _get_field_info function does a little bit of extra inference and validation so that this will always work, particularly for user-defined fields that aren't necessarily a tuple in the field_info dictionary.

content.raw:
@atmyers : This is super excellent work--a very comprehensive, advanced, and useful addition to the code.  I have a few small things I wanted to ask about it.

The `AxisAlignedParticlePlot` seems like a projection as opposed to a slice, right?  What I mean is, you're just taking the two spatial fields (e.g. `particle_x` and `particle_y`) and plotting them up regardless of any other depth field (e.g. `particle_z`)?  When the splats (or pixels) of particles overlap, you add them together to give you different values on the colorbar scale for the quantity provided, I think.  If this is true, perhaps the class name should reflect this so maybe `AxisAlignedParticleProjectionPlot` (quite a mouthful) is more apt, and changing the references in the docs/comments from being like a `SlicePlot` to being like a `ProjectionPlot`.  What do you (and others) think?

Also, is it at all possible to change the size of the splats for the particles?  Or are they at a fixed size of one/pixel?  I could see this being useful with the projections.  It's OK if there isn't a way right now--this could be something for the future.  Just curious.

Would you mind adding some basic tests into the code so we make sure if future development breaks this infrastructure, we know about it?  This can be as simple as unit tests that just *make* an `AxisAlignedParticlePlot` and a `ParticlePhasePlot` and save them.  A good example to copy off of might be a simplified version of `TestPlotWindowSave` in the `yt/visualization/tests/test_plotwindow.py`.  Don't hesitate to ask me or the other developers for help on this.

At the very bottom of your sample notebook: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/2d9a693b366c40bfee5d , you apply a weight_field to your data as well as provide a field for use as the quantity to be mapped in the colorbar.  But by setting the weight_field and the colormap field to be the same (the particle mass), everything goes to a single value of particle mass, and it seems like we lose the weighted sum.  Is this a bug, or is this by design?

Lastly, in your other notebook: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/29c5f8b82585d8800183/Particle%20Plot%20Examples.ipynb , on plot 5, you generate a ParticlePhasePlot showing using the particle_ones field as the colormap.  Does it make sense to hard code the ParticlePlot to recognize particle_ones and replace it in the plot label as "Particle Count", since I think this is more accurate? It's a minor thing, but if it is an easy change, it might make this a bit more intelligible to outsider viewers.

Again, overall, great work!
content.html:
Andrew Myers : This is super excellent work--a very comprehensive, advanced, and useful addition to the code. I have a few small things I wanted to ask about it.

The AxisAlignedParticlePlot seems like a projection as opposed to a slice, right? What I mean is, you're just taking the two spatial fields (e.g. particle_x and particle_y) and plotting them up regardless of any other depth field (e.g. particle_z)? When the splats (or pixels) of particles overlap, you add them together to give you different values on the colorbar scale for the quantity provided, I think. If this is true, perhaps the class name should reflect this so maybe AxisAlignedParticleProjectionPlot (quite a mouthful) is more apt, and changing the references in the docs/comments from being like a SlicePlot to being like a ProjectionPlot. What do you (and others) think?

Also, is it at all possible to change the size of the splats for the particles? Or are they at a fixed size of one/pixel? I could see this being useful with the projections. It's OK if there isn't a way right now--this could be something for the future. Just curious.

Would you mind adding some basic tests into the code so we make sure if future development breaks this infrastructure, we know about it? This can be as simple as unit tests that just make an AxisAlignedParticlePlot and a ParticlePhasePlot and save them. A good example to copy off of might be a simplified version of TestPlotWindowSave in the yt/visualization/tests/test_plotwindow.py. Don't hesitate to ask me or the other developers for help on this.

At the very bottom of your sample notebook: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/2d9a693b366c40bfee5d , you apply a weight_field to your data as well as provide a field for use as the quantity to be mapped in the colorbar. But by setting the weight_field and the colormap field to be the same (the particle mass), everything goes to a single value of particle mass, and it seems like we lose the weighted sum. Is this a bug, or is this by design?

Lastly, in your other notebook: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/29c5f8b82585d8800183/Particle%20Plot%20Examples.ipynb , on plot 5, you generate a ParticlePhasePlot showing using the particle_ones field as the colormap. Does it make sense to hard code the ParticlePlot to recognize particle_ones and replace it in the plot label as "Particle Count", since I think this is more accurate? It's a minor thing, but if it is an easy change, it might make this a bit more intelligible to outsider viewers.

Again, overall, great work!

content.raw:
Hi Cameron,

Thanks a bunch for going over this!

You're right about AxisAlignedSlicePlot is doing, and I agree that the spatial particle plots are more like projections than slices and should be described that way in the docs. Note that you can pass a "depth" argument that will control the thickness of the projection, but they are still splatting all the particles in some 3D region, not a 2D region. Maybe a more concise name would be "SpatialParticlePlot", since that is really what distinguishes it from the other particle plots. Or just "AxisAlignedParticlePlot"? I'll solicit opinions about this on the users list when I ask for feedback there.

Currently, it's not possible to change the size of the particles. I agree that this would be a useful addition down the road.

On the tests, I agree. I'll write up some tests that do just that.

On setting the z_field and the weight_field to be the same, that's the behavior I intended - it's showing the total z_field in each pixel divided by the total weight_field. But now that you mention it I guess it's not really correct to call it a "weight_field" in that case. Really, the behavior should be the same as PhasePlot, so it should show sum(z_field*weight_field) / sum(weight_field).

On the subject of weighting, should the weight_field for particle plots default to "particle_ones", so it displays the mean value in each pixel? That seems more meaningful than a total quantity that depends on your bin size.

I agree that the display name should be "Particle Count" - can this be accomplished just by setting a display_name for the "particle_ones" field when it's created?

Thanks again for your comments,
Andrew
content.html:
Hi Cameron,

Thanks a bunch for going over this!

You're right about AxisAlignedSlicePlot is doing, and I agree that the spatial particle plots are more like projections than slices and should be described that way in the docs. Note that you can pass a "depth" argument that will control the thickness of the projection, but they are still splatting all the particles in some 3D region, not a 2D region. Maybe a more concise name would be "SpatialParticlePlot", since that is really what distinguishes it from the other particle plots. Or just "AxisAlignedParticlePlot"? I'll solicit opinions about this on the users list when I ask for feedback there.

Currently, it's not possible to change the size of the particles. I agree that this would be a useful addition down the road.

On the tests, I agree. I'll write up some tests that do just that.

On setting the z_field and the weight_field to be the same, that's the behavior I intended - it's showing the total z_field in each pixel divided by the total weight_field. But now that you mention it I guess it's not really correct to call it a "weight_field" in that case. Really, the behavior should be the same as PhasePlot, so it should show sum(z_field*weight_field) / sum(weight_field).

On the subject of weighting, should the weight_field for particle plots default to "particle_ones", so it displays the mean value in each pixel? That seems more meaningful than a total quantity that depends on your bin size.

I agree that the display name should be "Particle Count" - can this be accomplished just by setting a display_name for the "particle_ones" field when it's created?

Thanks again for your comments, Andrew

content.raw: I agree - I'll send out such an email tomorrow.
content.html: I agree - I'll send out such an email tomorrow.

content.raw: I couldn't decide whether CIC deposition made sense for logarithmically-spaced bins. For NGP deposition, there is nothing preventing it. I guess it could only force logs to be False if deposition is 'cic'.
content.html: I couldn't decide whether CIC deposition made sense for logarithmically-spaced bins. For NGP deposition, there is nothing preventing it. I guess it could only force logs to be False if deposition is 'cic'.

content.html: I agree, and actually I think we should put all the particle plotting classes here (not ParticleProfile or ParticleImageBuffer, but the PlotWindow or PhasePlot -derived classes)

In particular, there are now tests, there is a new display name for "particle_ones" and weight_field works as it should. Thanks again for you comments, the weight_field thing in particular was a good catch.

content.raw: In the PR review hangout, we like the idea of changing the name to ``ParticleProjectionPlot`` instead of ``AxisAlignedParticlePlot``.  This is more consistent with the naming scheme we have right now with ``ProjectionPlot`` and ``OffAxisProjectionPlot``.  Other than that renaming, this is good to go.

content.raw:
Hey @atmyers , sorry for the long hiatus on the PR comments.  All of your corrections look great.  In particular, thanks for making the tests on this.  As @brittonsmith suggests, the only remaining thing I think should change is making the `AxisAlignedParticlePlot` change to `ParticleProjectionPlot` just for consistency sake.  Because in the grid plots, we have `ProjectionPlot` (on-axis) and `OffAxisProjectionPlot`, and then `SlicePlot` (on-axis) and `OffAxisSlicePlot`, I think it only makes sense to have your particle plot class be: `ParticleProjectionPlot` since it is a particle equivalent to the `ProjectionPlot`.  What do you think?

Other than that, this looks awesome.  Thanks so much for your hard work.
content.html:
Hey Andrew Myers , sorry for the long hiatus on the PR comments. All of your corrections look great. In particular, thanks for making the tests on this. As Britton Smith suggests, the only remaining thing I think should change is making the AxisAlignedParticlePlot change to ParticleProjectionPlot just for consistency sake. Because in the grid plots, we have ProjectionPlot (on-axis) and OffAxisProjectionPlot, and then SlicePlot (on-axis) and OffAxisSlicePlot, I think it only makes sense to have your particle plot class be: ParticleProjectionPlot since it is a particle equivalent to the ProjectionPlot. What do you think?

Other than that, this looks awesome. Thanks so much for your hard work.

description:
This PR implements new particle plotting functions. There are two main additions. First, there are new classes for handling PlotWindow-style particle plots, in which both the axes are spatial.  There is a  ``` ParticleImageBuffer ``` class thats works like a ``` FixedResolutionBuffer ``` and an ``` AxisAlignedParticlePlot ``` class for making the plots. ```AxisAlignedParticlePlot ``` inherits from ``` PWViewerMPL ``` and the relevant modification functions and callbacks should work normally. 

Second, there is now a ```ParticleProfile``` class for plotting arbitrary particle fields against each other, and a ```ParticlePhasePlot``` class that handles their construction automatically. You can construct the profiles either by binning the particles or by doing CIC deposition. 

The use of these features is demonstrated in [this](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/c965c769a488016c3299) notebook.

Documentation is here: http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_docs/26/artifact/sandbox/doc/build/html/visualizing/plots.html#particle-plots

Cookbook recipes are here:
http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_docs/26/artifact/sandbox/doc/build/html/cookbook/simple_plots.html#simple-particle-plot
